Jason Gauci wrote:
> 
> In the example you provided, there is only one update. As you

Sorry, I should have said to imagine running that sequence a second or 
third time, upon which you should see the recurrent link working 
properly, as expected.  Of course, the first time through, the recurrent 
link has no influence (since the node behind it is initially inactive).

> So, even using your method, you have to decide how many times you
> would like to update the network, and that number will change the
> value of the output.

Not really.  Using my method you only update it once, regardless.  Yes, 
there are cases where it will treat recurrency slightly differently.  In 
my admittedly trivial example network, though, I don't see any difference.

As Ken pointed out, it's just a different way of doing the update.  I 
like it because it's very simple, and obviously faster than updating a 
network multiple times.

I do not come from the world of Academia, and hadn't realized, as Ken 
said, that the [update in arbitrary order until stable] update method 
was more common.  My world is one of real-time interactivity (console 
video games), to give you an idea of my frame of mind.

Let's assume we can poll a particular wireless controller device at 
around 50Hz, in hopes of recognizing some physical gestures.  You can 
see then where doing a single update per sample is considerably more 
attractive.

--Steve
